text: CLOSE on Cornelia Srebnick, 41. She’s humming softly. We MOVE out slowly to see she’s rocking the infant on a big comfortable couch fionlled with baby blankets, stuffed animals and children’s books. We MOVE over to see Josh Srebnick, 44, on the floor watch her -- his expression a kind of awe. She looks at him, hesitating, taken by the intensity of his look. A moment connection and warmth passes through her. He smiles softly back.
(to the baby) There were three little pigs and they made a house out of twigs and the wolf came and... (to Josh) Do you remember how it goes?
He blows it down? The baby starts to fuss.
Yeah. But, what happens in the middle?
(thinks ) I keep wanting to do this little piggie went to market but that’s with the toes. The baby starts to cry.

The wolf keeps blowing the house in. The pigs keep making different houses. (rocks the baby) Oh...shh, shh, shh. The baby is wailing. Cornelia rocks her faster. She looks panicked.  Pink (09/30/2013) 2.
What the fuck do we do? Josh doesn't know. Bang, a door opens and a woman comes i with a boppy strapped around her waist. This is Marina, 30's.
Okay, who’s ready to eat?

Are we taking in or -- Who’s ready to eat? She sits down on the couch next to Cornelia, lifts the sobbing infant from out of Cornelia’s arms and places it the boppy. The baby’s onesie has an image from The Clash’ first album across the chest. Marina opens her bra and gi the baby her breast. The baby nurses, stretches and stops crying.

Ha! I love how she stretches...it’s just like we do... It’s so funny. It never occurred to me that stretching is innate. She stretches, imitating the baby. Cornelia smiles polite A curly haired man with glasses, early 40's, enters. Flet
You want to see it?
Yeah. Fletcher sits near Josh.
It got infected with staph but it’s not the bad staph. He pushes up his sleeve to reveal a square black and whit tattoo on his bicep.
What is it?
Guess. (to Josh) You can come closer it’s not the bad staph.  He shoves Pink (09/30/2013)
I still don’t want the baby touching it. his shoulder in Josh’s face.
I can’t...tell.
It’s Willow’s sonogram.
Oh...okay.
I did it for Marina. I was so fucking proud of her.
Why it’s for me, I still don’t understand.
Where do you even go for a tattoo?
I asked a guy at work and he told me where his kids went. Place in Williamsburg. Where else? (pause) You know, she didn’t get the epidurol.
It’s a mother fucker -- it’s a ring of fucking fire -- but it was the most beautiful experience of my life.
And I fell in love immediately. A love I’ve never felt. I mean, don’t take that the wrong way, Marina --
No, I know exactly what you mean. It’s pure.
(how sweet) Aww...
(can’t help herself) Oh, you guys should do it!
Yeah!
You’d make such good parents. (catching herself) I’m sorry, I’m sorry!
No, it’s fine. You know, we -- She looks at Josh.
We... It’s just such a game changer! We STAY on Josh and Cornelia’s faces.
When I saw her, I thought: “I know you.”
It’s true, I recognized her immediately.
And because I'd been reading to her in the womb, she knew my voice immediately.
It’s like in one moment, I read her Stephen King’s The + everything is different. Tommyknockers.
It’s like all the stuff before, fine, you know, we’re figuring it out, but now: Okay, real life. You know? Josh and Cornelia nod.

location: COBBLE HILL STREETS, BROOKLYN. DAY A2

text: Cornelia and Josh walk home.  Pink (09/30/2013) 4a. INT. JOSH AND CORNELIA’S APARTMENT. DAY 2 They enter. An open floor-through of a brownstone. The room, separated by large wooden pocket doors, looks half- finished, framed pictures lean against the wall, projects undertaken and abandoned. Some nice stuff, a couple of antique chairs or a table. A water stain untended to on t ceiling.
I can’t remember Goldilocks either anymore. The porridge part, but not what happens.
She gets eaten, right?
Does she?
There’s like an oven that’s too hot. Josh shrugs. Silence.

You don’t want kids, right? (Josh hesitates) Because I don’t. (they both hesitate) I’m sorry, I feel so guilty for saying that. I mean, I did. If we'd had the magic sexy version and one day suddenly had a baby... But all those drugs and shots and miscarriages -- I don’t want to do it again and it not to work.
I know. (beat) And I like our life as it is.
(relieved) Me too.
I don’t want things to be different than they are right now.
I know. I mean, if we wanted to take off for Paris tomorrow, we could.
Yeah, I mean I think it would be hard to find an affordable fare on such short notice, but yeah...
No, I know and I couldn’t leave work.
If we were going to do it we should plan it at least a month in advance.
A month is still in the realm of spontaneity.
No, I know. I mean, the time we spent in Rome, what was that --
(can’t believe it) It wasn’t 2006.
Yeah because I was working with my dad on his dance film.
Rome was eight years ago already? Shit.
Yeah, I looked at the pictures recently and we’re two younger people standing at the Treve Fountain.
We look similar.
We look younger. (pause) I tried to get you to go to Mexico last summer --
I needed to finish my documentary.
But you didn’t finish it! They both take a deep breath. Pause.
Well, maybe the point is we have the freedom. What we do with it isn’t that important.
Marina said they haven't had sex in nearly a year. Fletcher was too weirded out by the pregnancy.
God.
They eat Thai take-out at a table set for two.
They do dishes. INT. JOSH/CORNELIA APT. - BEDROOM, COBBLE HILL, BROOKLYN.

Josh, in his boxers, takes off his watch and puts it on t night table. Cornelia undresses. They move about in silence, finishing their nighttime routines. Only the sounds of footsteps, water running, clothes coming off and going on, bed squeaks. Josh lies on his back and shuts his eyes. Cornelia gets in bed and clicks on her bedside lamp which lights up nearly everything. Josh places his arm over his eyes.
What is that, a seventy-five watt? She looks under the shade.
I can’t see, it’s too bright.
It’s too high a wattage.
I‘1l change it tomorrow.
Josh paces back and forth in his home-office. His editor, Tim, early 30’s, sits at a desk-top attached to a series drives. A tousled scholar, Ira Mandelstam, 50’s, talks gravely on a TV screen.
There was a poll conducted in 1987 in which people were given a series of phrases and asked which ones could be found in the US Constitution --
Let me see the continuity...

One of the phrases that got the highest percentage of votes was: “From each according to his ability, to each according to his need.” This, of course, is not to be found in the Constitution, but is the famous Communist credo popularized by Karl Marx. Josh takes the sheet and holds it about two feet from his face. He squints.
Why do they type this stuff so small?
I think that’s 12 point. That’s normal.
However, when this phrase was That is not 12, that’s at presented to people as a most eight. Look at it, it’s tenet of Communism, they, of tiny. course, overwhelmingly rejected it.
We need to cut away from Ira here because... We hear a ringing. On the SCREEN: the scholar goes into h pants pocket and retrieves a cell phone from a few years
Hold on... He looks at it like he’s never seen anything like it befo He puts on reading glasses and very deliberately presses Talk.
Hello?...Evelyn, I’m doing an interview...Did you look in the car? This is every fucking day, sweety! (MORE )

I keep telling you: put them on a fucking chain around your neck! (mouths to the camera) Sorry. (back to the phone) Sweety, if you don’t stop this, I’m going to fucking screa -- Tim freezes the image on the screen.
We could cut to me asking the question about hermeneutics?
We could, but you look like this in that footage -- He shows an image of a younger Josh in a goatee and Jew-f
It’s from eight years ago. And the previous shot of you asking any relevant questions is this -- He pulls up an image of Josh with short hair and his arm sling.

That’s from when I fell down the subway stairs at Grand Army Plaza. The blizzard of 06? You remember how icy that was? We CUT between a series of Joshes from over the years. Different hair lengths, a beard, a brief moustache, a bla eye.
You remember, I was trying my part on the other side. Tim doesn't.
God, eight years ago. Has it been that long?
It’s been ten.
(counting in his head, rationalizing) (MORE )
Ten this fall. Nine and a half. Look at my jaw -- I had more baby fat. (looks at his reflection in the computer screen) Are my eyes getting hollows?
I don’t know.
(trying to be positive) Well...we’re getting there. Tim looks at him, totally skeptical.
When the rest of the grant money comes in, we'll reshoot me asking the questions along with the trip to Istanbul.
Hey, Josh, I hate to bring this up, but I’m gonna need a little money soon.
No, I know, you've been patient. I’m just waiting for the rest of this last grant money.
But soon?
Yeah, I’1l get you. Goes into his wallet.
You need anything now? He hands Tim a couple of twenties.
You know, get Maggie some flowers or...
I’m going to use it to buy food.
Oh, yeah, yeah...good idea.  Blue (09/16/2013) 11.
A room with about fifty chairs, about seven of them occup by people over 50. Josh stands at a lectern with a lap to A blank TV screen behind him.

“Le documentaire, c'est ce qui arrive aux autres, la fiction, c'est ce qui m'arrive a moi.” “Documentary is about someone else. Fiction is about me.” (glances out at the small crowd, having made it through the French part) This is a quote from Jean-Luc Godard. Now, what do we think about this? Can a documentary be personal? Documentaries, I want to say to you today, can and should be about me. Josh hesitates. A guy in the audience wearing a porkpie h is filming him with a portable camera. Josh is momentaril distracted.
Me meaning all of us. (to the room) Lights. (pause) Frank, can you just hit that switch? An elderly gentleman obliges. Josh hits a button on his l top.
This is an image from -- Nothing happens on the screen behind him. Josh presses th button again. Nothing.

Well...shit...this should be an image of seal hunting from “Nanook of The North.” CUT TO: Josh collects his things from a chair at the foot the stage. A squat woman, 50’s, who runs the lecture seri shrugs and smiles tightly at him.
Sorry.  Blue (09/16/2013) lia.

(suddenly paranoid) About what?  Blue (09/16/2013) 12. The guy, 25, who was shooting Josh, comes forward. He wea his mussed hair under his porkpie hat, an old plaid shirt hanging out over slacks, and beat up boots. This is Jamie
Hey. Beautiful class.
Oh...thanks. I don’t know why the power point didn’t work, but...
I loved what you said about “hyper- reality.” I’m Jamie.
Josh Srebnick. This is my wife, Darby. A girl, 23, in a high waisted dress and lace up boots com forward.
Hi. Nice to meet you. It was interesting.
Thanks. I’m not sure why the power point didn’t work... How did you get in here?
We're auditing your class.
It’s a continuing education class, you can’t audit a continuing education class.
(shrugs) I’m a fan. And hey, I really loved your film, Power Elite.
(taken aback, can’t hide his pleasure) You've seen it? Hey...thanks.
It’s everything I aspire to and you make it look so easy.
Do you make documentaries?  Blue (09/16/2013) 13.
I shoot stuff, you know, with friends, yeah. Nothing like you’re doing.
He’s always shooting.
Um, don’t take this the wrong way, but how did you see Power Elite?
I found a VHS on Ebay. I paid like sixty dollars for it. You know what was great, was that scene with the dogs around the garbage? How did you stage that?
Oh...those dogs were just there and I said, “Hey shoot those dogs.” (not a great story) And...we did.
(claps his hands together) Beautiful.
I’ve been working on this other one for...about eight years now but I think I’m zeroing in on it.
I'd love to see it.

When I was a child my dog was killed in front of me by two rottweilers. (she starts to laugh) I don’t know why I’m laughing. It’s not funny. I was five. My dad and I were walking our poodle which I had named Toto and these two rottweilers came bounding out of an open gate and just attacked. My dad flagged down a passing car and we climbed in the back and he covered my eyes so I couldn’t see Toto get mauled. She covers her face, she’s still laughing.  14.
(hesitates) I’m sorry to hear that.
You want to come get a bite with us?
Oh...I’m meeting my...wife around the corner at this Chinese place.
Hey, my wife and I are going to the same goddamn place!
Josh and Cornelia sit next to each other. Josh is in the middle of talking to Jamie and Darby who face them across table.
...I’ve learned along the way that you can discover more by not knowing the answers, by allowing yourself to be surprised by what you encounter. Jamie nods with great interest.
Yeah, yeah.
Sometimes that means waiting years for something to happen. I don’t know. I could go on about this stuff for days.
How did you start out, like who influenced you?
Oh, I steal from everyone, you know, Maysles, Wiseman, Pennebaker... My first job out of graduate school was working for Leslie Breitbart.
(impressed) Jeez Louise.  15.
That’s also incidentally how I met Cornelia. He’s her dad.
What?!
This is before they hated each other.
We don’t hate each other. Cornelia produces her dad’s films.
He’s amazing.
Yeah, he’s kind of annoying me right now, but...yeah.
He’s a giant. He’s a guy I’d love to meet. Do you also produce Josh's films?
No, Josh likes to work alone.
(again with real interest, to Josh) Josh, what's your new film about?

Well, I’m trying to solve the problem that Eisenstein never solved -- that is how to make a film that is both materialist and intellectual at the same time -- Darby gets a text and starts to reply. Jamie yawns openly Josh feels he’s losing his audience but keeps going.

It’s about the distinctly American relationship between biography and history, theory and method and how that relates to power and class in our country, particularly the political, military and economic elite. (sensing he’s lost them) It’s really about America.  Blue (09/16/2013) 16. Jamie takes out a pad and pen and scribbles something dow
Eisenstein is astonishing. I just saw Strike! I’m obsessed with Europe in the 20’s, see. The interwar period, ex-patriots, that sort of thing.
I keep trying to get Jamie to do something with before and afters. All humans love before and afters. Any TV show with before and afters will succeed.
(smiles broadly) Before you said that. (Jamie frowns) After you said that.
(shakes her head) Fuck you. He grabs her breast she smacks his hand playfully and ret to her phone and answers a text. Cornelia tries an accommodating smile.
What do you do, Darby?
Darby makes ice cream.
Oh, yeah?
(shrugs, texting) Yeah, I make ice cream.
I brought it over to the Whole Foods near us and they’re pumped.
It’s Jamie’s idea to sell it, I just do it because I like it.
And you guys are married?  Blue (09/16/2013) 16A. They both nod in unison.  17.
That’s so nice and old fashioned.
Yeah. We said our vows in an empty water tower in Harlem.
Oh.
There was a mariachi band and a slip and slide.
Wow.
Jamie wanted a big wedding. It was amazing. Some rituals exist for a reason, you know.
(glances at Josh) Yeah. We did it at city hall.
(looking up from a text) Isaac and Benny are walking the tracks.
Have you guys done this? We walked through the subway tunnels on the D line last week.
(as if it’s commonplace) No, no, we haven’t.
They’re at a Bar on Essex. You want to come?
(to Cornelia) Oh, do we -- ?
It’s already past our bedtime.
(sheepishly) Yeah, we’re usually in bed by eleven.  Blue (09/16/2013) 18. The check is placed on the table. Anticipating some resistance, Josh puts his hand on the check.
Let me get it.
(eagerly) Thanks.
Yeah, thanks. Josh's hand remains on the check in preparation for it to taken from him. Nothing happens.
No, yeah, I'll get it.
Jamie and Darby unlock their bikes which are chained to a street-sign with old-school bike chains. Jamie attaches t chain to his pants like an accessory.
If you’ve got any time -- and I know you’re super busy -- I’d love to show you what I’m working on.
Come by our place this weekend. (to Cornelia) I have my fall flavors. Jamie gives Josh an old Polaroid of himself and writes hi number on it with a sharpie. His handwriting is in all ca very precise.
They don’t make this film anymore. I bought four hundred packs before they discontinued it. Jamie, without a helmet, hops on his bike which has a crocheted seat. Darby is still tying her helmet.
Let’s go, worm! (to Josh and Cornelia) Peace.  Pink (09/30/2013) 19.

(to Josh and Cornelia) Jamie is always moving. I can’t leap as fast as that kid. I don’t move as quickly. They both pedal into the center of the street. The streetlight giving them a kind of glow. We MOVE in on Jos and Cornelia. They don’t know what hit them.
I like how engaged they are in everything.
Cornelia is reading on her Kindle. Josh stands in the bathroom doorway.
Mm.

They're all making things and they’re so excited for each other. It’s selfless. They were so respectful of us. I mean, compared to when we go out with Fletcher and Marina I feel like we're all just talking about ourselves... They asked questions.
They didn’t ask me any questions.
When I was their age I would never have come up to me like that and invited me out. I would have been too scared... They’re really not nervous.
I wish you hadn’t told him I work with my dad.
Why?
I don’t know, he seems ambitious.
No! I don’t think he thinks that way. It’s about process.  He climbs Blue (09/16/2013) 20.
How has he even seen anything of yours?
(like it should be obvious) Ebay. (scanning the room) I love his shoes. I have some wing tips here somewhere. into bed.
It was almost like he was studying you.
Can we go to their place this weekend?
We never see our real friends, why are we suddenly going to hang out with a couple of twenty-five year olds.
We were just twenty-five. I mean, we weren’t, but you know. It’1l be fun. CUT TO: CLOSE on a woman, 25, scrolling through the addre on her phone.
Um, let’s see, it would probably be...Richard Dreyfuss. He’s an old friend of my parents.
Um, this girl who was a writer on that show, Medium. YELLOW BLOCK TEXT on the screen: Who’s the most famous pe in your cell phone?
Doug Liman. Guy #2 Bill Clinton. But I think it’s probably his office.
Patrick Ewing’s brother. Carl.  21. Guy #2 (now on his phone) Ringing. (pause) Yeah, it’s his office.
Robert Downey. Senior.
Jamie watches Josh and Cornelia watch the short on his computer. They’re both smiling. Darby hovers in the background, holding a white kitten, she’s seen it.
That’s really funny.
Yeah. I like Robert Downey. Senior.

That’s the latest anyway. I’m also doing people describing scenes from movies that they like but haven't seen in a while. Darby’s going to do Rosemary's Baby, see. Josh and Cornelia look back at Darby. She obliges:
What have you done to its eyes!?
(playing along) He has his father’s eyes. Cornelia pets the kitten in Darby’s arms.
I want a kitten!
That’s Bad Cop. Where’s Good Cop? A black kitten comes out from under the couch. Darby hand the white one to Cornelia and gathers the other one.
I love these kittens, but I hope they don’t grow up to be assholes because that can happen.  22.
This is a great space. You know I think I’ve only been to Williamsburg once before.
This isn’t even Williamsburg, it’s Bushwick. We were in Williamsburg, before then Park Slope, now we're here. (shrugs) We live where we’re supposed to live. She indicates a series of old typewriters.

Jamie’s a collector. My decorating sensibilities veer towards 4th grade teacher. I like bulletin boards. We see the place now. It’s old, open, and has the feel of being haphazardly curated: from the mouse trap stuck to t molding to the flea market furniture to the VHS tapes of random movies stacked against the wall. A framed NY Times front page of the moon landing. A framed Polish poster of the Bob Dylan doc “Don’t Look Back.” A photo of Darby goi down a slip and slide in her wedding dress. Josh looks at a stack of records. Velvet Underground, Kin John Coltrane, Suicide, Serge Gainsbourg, Thin Lizzy...

This looks like my record collection. Except mine are CD’s. It took me years to discover this stuff. Jamie smiles and puts a record on the turntable. A Notori B.I.G/Miley Cyrus mash-up. Josh admires a long wooden des with a computer and editing equipment.
I need to buy a new desk.
You should come with me to the lumber yard. We’ll make one.
A whole desk?
It’s so much cheaper than buying one, see. And more fun. (MORE )
Joshy, don’t overpay at some douche farm like a chump. A dark haired girl, 26, appears, in underwear and a T-shi with the drawing of a gun as if it’s tucked into her pant
Darby, can I borrow your bike, I’m going to the deli for Goldfish.
Okay -- Tipper lifts her long bare leg and scratches the bottom o her foot.
Tipper, did you feed Nico?
(disappearing into the other room) I forgot. Off Cornelia’s perplexed look:

(with a hint of disdain) That’s our roommate, Tipper. Jamie grabs a bag of bird seed from a counter, he opens a small door that leads to an outdoor landing. A chicken pa in a cage. Cornelia hesitates.
Nico’s a chicken. CUT TO: They sit around a small table. Darby prepares something in the kitchen.
I have to say I really admire how you guys are so in the moment and just enjoying doing and making things. It’s inspiring.
Thanks, Joshy.
The people our age are so success and results oriented, they've forgotten about process.  24.
Josh, are you success oriented?
No. Totally. Josh looks at Cornelia, surprised. A crash from the kitch Darby reenters, shaking her head.
I feel like there are people who don’t drop things as much as I do. (to Cornelia) I don’t keep things yar.
She’s a mess. And an ugly eater. I say that with love.
(playful) Fuck you. Darby places down a home-made container with a hipster co it and four spoons. She and Jamie eat straight from the container. Josh and Cornelia follow.
It’s an avocado and almond milk sorbet. Benny designed the container.
It tastes like that candy that they sometimes make into pigs or little fruits.
Yeah, it’s... Shit. I know that.
I keep wanting to say baklava, but that’s a Greek dessert.
Right... “The almond tasting pigs and fruits are made of...” Josh pulls out his phone.
(realizes, excited) I‘1l look it up.  Al0
clo
No, that’s too easy.
Let’s try to remember it. They all sit in silence, racking their brains.
How long until we decide we don’t know?
(re: his phone) Can I...now?
No, let’s just not know what it is. CUT TO: Technology MONTAGE: INT. JOSH/CORNELIA APT. DAY Al0 Cornelia reads her Kindle. Josh watches a Daily Show vide on his phone.
Jamie removes a VHS tape of The Howling from a beat up bo and slides it into the VCR. INT. JOSH/CORNELIA APT. DAY c10 Josh streams a movie on Apple TV.
Darby puts a worn Kris Kristofferson record on a turntabl She secures old-fashioned headphones to her head.
Cornelia selects a NPR podcast from her iPod mini and put her sleek noise-reduction Bose headphones.
Jamie types a letter on an old IBM Selectric typewriter.
Josh plays a video game on his iPad.
110 10 Pink (09/30/2013) 26. The chicken sleeps in his cage. END MONTAGE.
CUT TO: CLOSE on a text being typed: Joshy, street beach in effect! get your goddamn self to t wick for bourbon and ice creeeeem. CUT TO: CLOSE on a hand receiving the same text.
We have news!

location: RESTAURANT, SMITH ST. BROOKLYN. LATE DAY 10

text: Josh sneaks a look at his text, smiles. Fletcher and Mari Josh and Cornelia sit at a table at the window. Throughou the conversation, everyone is dealing with his/her phone.
I decided, with Marina going back to work, I’m taking a leave of absence from the firm and am going to take care of Willow.
Oh...cool. How long?
Indefinite.
It’s such a load off and I’m making enough --
Yeah, it’s really just my ego at stake.
Time to rewatch Mr. Mom. Already Netflixed it. I got some laughs.
We're the boring couple with the baby. What have you guys been doing? Tell us something fun!
Well, we met this interesting couple. Jamie and Darby. He’s a young documentarian and she makes ice cream.
I don’t know what to make of them honestly. I like her.
They make everything. It’s infectious. For about twelve hours I thought I could build my own desk.
There is something about being around them that...that energizes you. You know?
How old are they?
(looks to Josh) 26 or 27. I think around 26.
They’re children!
Nine years ago, they couldn’t vote.
But they’re married.
Why? Josh squints at his menu. He picks up a candle and holds close to the menu in order to read.

You should see this guy’s record collection. It’s Jay-Z, it’s Thin Lizzy, it’s Mozart. Their taste is democratic. It’s The Goonies and Citizen Kane. They don’t distinguish between high and low, it’s wonderful.
When did The Goonies become a good movie?

It’s like their apartment is full of everything we once threw out but it looks so good the way they have it.  Pink (09/30/2013) 28. Silence. Josh feels his phone vibrate. He starts texting. Everyone else takes this opportunity to text as well. Fletcher looks up.
(re: texting) Why is it once one person goes on their phone everyone else has to.
(distracted, on her (distracted, on her phone) phone) I just have a quick thing-- I’m not on my phone. I’m just... The baby.
Each of us is so certain that we’ve got the most important thing to do right now...
(texting) I know, it’s rude.
(texting) It’s not anymore. It used to be but now it’s accepted. It’s like showing your ankles in the 1800's. Josh gets a text. He lights up.
The almond tasting pigs and fruits are made of... CLOSE: Marzipan! He and Cornelia both exclaim, laughing:
Marzipan!
It’s still light out. They emerge from the restaurant.
(to Fletcher and Marina) You guys want to hit this street beach with us?  Pink (09/30/2013) 28a.
I don’t know what you’re saying.
Something Jamie and Darby are doing.
Since when do you guys do two things in an evening? You never go anywhere.  Pink (09/30/2013) 29,
(defensive) We go anywhere.
We have to get back for the sitter...Scratch that, we want to get back.
I hate being away from her!
The sitter?
Yeah! (beat) No, Willow.
You should see how much he It’s true. cries when he has to leave her.
Oh, we’ve lost you to the baby!
You guys have to come see her We're always home so just again! She’s already a stop by! different person. They kiss and hug goodbye. They part ways.
(now to Josh) We have lost them to the baby.
We go anywhere. Right?
We never go anywhere.
High kick contest!

CLOSE on an open fire hydrant hemorrhaging water.  30. Tipper, in a a home-made, totally unofficial t-shirt that says I’ve Been To A Lot of Hard Rock Cafes, kicks her leg high in the air. Guys in vintage plaid shorts and porkpie hats and beards and bare feet try to kick higher. Most everyone is filming everyone. Young women in swim suits t a beach ball. Jamie, with an apron that says Kiss the Chef, finishes kicking and sees Josh and Cornelia approaching. He bright and waves.
What’s the rumpus, Srebnicks? Darby hands Cornelia a pinkish drink in a clear plastic c

Have you tried this? Someone at college figured out that if you put Jolly Ranchers in vodka for twenty- four hours -- it’s awesome. (nods to herself) Some kind of date rape genius. Cornelia drinks, she nods.
I’d rape me.
You want to take a dance class with me?
Ow fuck! Benny, a bearded white kid in an afro, sits at the curb, wincing and pulling a piece of glass out of his foot. Jam and Josh wade through the bathers to a hibachi grill.
Can I run an idea by you?
Sure, what?
It’s a project I want to shoot.
Okay.  31.

You know, I was going through a tough time in highschool, my mom was really sick with ovarian cancer, I was pretty promiscuous, but I couldn’t love anyone, I had body issues -- We slowly ZOOM in on Jamie as he talks. Josh's closed eye opens. While keeping the camera trained Jamie, he inspects it, bewildered. He’s not pressing anything. He sees -- Jamie holds a small remote in his hand. He’s zooming in o himself.
You had written a poem for English, you were this athlete and you wrote this beautiful poem. Do you know what poem I’m talking about?
I wrote a lot of poems.
It was a line, very simple, but effective, “I want to be unbridgeable.” That one line got me through my mother’s illness.  Blue (09/16/2013) 63.
Yeah? I don’t know why I stopped writing poetry. I stopped doing a lot of things. Why do we stop doing things? I guess life happens.
Life is other plans.
Yeah.
(from behind the camera) Life is what happens when you're making other plans. Jamie and Kent both startle and turn to the camera.
(again annoyed) Who is he?
I keep trying to get people to agree with me on this: I hate Tipper.
Antiques and vintage clothing. Darby helps Cornelia lace a corset.
She ends every word she can with “ish.” I thought she was making fun of this way of talking until it was clear that she wasn’t.
She tries too hard.
Exactly! But it’s low-key so you don’t notice it. I shouldn’t shit- talk Tipper. I have so many things.
You and Jamie were highschool sweethearts?
No, Jamie was only in Santa Cruz for a semester. (MORE )
His dad worked for a medical supply company that was contracted by the army and they were never in one place very long. Jamie can be at home anywhere.
Josh is only at home at home.  43 64. The corset is laced. Cornelia turns and looks at herself the mirror. She’s horrified.
The four of them and Tipper in a booth. Jamie and Tipper have just finished telling Darby and Cornelia about the d Josh is looking at something on his phone.
He was soulful-ish, you know.
Sister, that’s an understatement. You can tell he’s been to some dark places.
(petulant) We went to some dark places too. I bought a dress. Cornelia didn’t buy a corset.
(eating) Mm, this burger is in-cred-ible.
(re: his phone) Holy shit.
What’s wrong?
No...nothing...I just Googled Kent... (looks up to Jamie) Did you Google him?
No, I wanted it to be fresh.
This...it’s there’s a picture, it’s the same guy. He was in Afghanistan.
(surprised) Really?
Yeah...he...this article says he was part of a massacre in Wanat. (MORE )

They opened fire on a bus full of civilians... He then spoke out publicly about it and then he refused to fight. He was jailed briefly then he returned to battle, was injured and given the Purple Heart.
You're kidding? Josh hands Jamie his phone. Jamie beams.
It says two men in his unit have killed themselves. Tipper -- Tipper gets out the camera and turns it on Josh. Josh loo into the lens strangely.
Do it again, what you did.
Which part?
The phone, the discovery, everything.
Oh... Josh awkwardly looks at his phone then back up. The four them are waiting.
(stilted) It’s the same guy... Is that what I said? How did I say it? Jamie yawns, impatiently. Josh tries again:
(acting now) It’s the same guy! Holy shit. Jamie, take a look at this. Tipper swings the camera at Jamie. He grabs Josh’s phone reacts almost identically.
It says two men in his unit have killed themselves.  66.
(excited, getting the hang of it) We have to go back!
Yeah?
We have to get him talking about this. This is the movie! Now it’s not just some stupid Facebook thing. Jamie looks at Josh oddly. Josh backtracks:
Not that that wasn’t a good idea too. But, and I hate this expression, but you stepped in shit! (suddenly) Cornelia!
(caught off guard) What?! Josh kisses her.
I don’t know! Jamie digs into his food.
Thank God I’ve got you, Joshy! We did what you said: we didn’t know the answers, we discovered it. I should get a good book on Afghanistan. And war in general. I really know so little about it.
(decides to go for it) You know who you should talk to. Ira Mandelstam, the guy in my film he could tell you a lot about war and the politics of war.
That’s your guy, though, Joshy. I can’t take your guy.  44 45 Blue (09/16/2013) 67.
I don’t care. I want to share him with you. (to the table) Look ma, I’m sharing!
Jeez Louise, that would be fucking beautiful.
(suddenly, caught up in the whole thing) You know, if you want help... I could help or...produce this for you... Josh looks at Cornelia, surprised. He smiles.
My dad’s between things now...

Oh, my God. Are you kidding, I'd be so pumped. Thank you, thank you. Josh keeps smiling. He wants very badly for this to feel good. INT. SCHOLAR’S APARTMENT 44 Ira, the scholar, is talking about the power structure of United States. Jamie shoots him. Tipper holds a boom. She wears a T-shirt that reads in generic lettering: A Colleg Didn't Go To. Cornelia stands close by. Josh sits ina chair in the back, listening through headphones. His eyes drift away from the scholar and turn inward. He looks alm afraid. INT. SCHOLAR’S BEDROOM 45 A mess of books and clothes and dogs and dog beds. Josh pulls Cornelia inside and shuts the door.
What?
(hushed) Can I say something I’m ashamed of?
Yeah.
It’s not generous. And I probably don't really mean it.
Okay. Go.
And I think Jamie’s great so --
Say it!

(snapping) I can’t fucking believe his idiotic Facebook idea paid off! It’s so fucking stupid! And my thing is a mess. A total fucking mess. (pause) Sorry, I feel bad saying that. But I also hate the fact he’s calling his band Cookie O’Puss.
What’s wrong with that?
It’s just some funny old kitschy thing to him he saw on YouTube. But that was my commercial. I actually experienced it. You know?
I don’t know from Cookie Puss.

Really? It was for Carvel. Cookie Puss was the original one but they did an ice cream cake for Saint Patrick’s Day and it was this floating green Irish cake that said, “My name is Cookie O’Puss.” Cornelia is silent.
(exhales) I’m being ridiculous. I probably don’t mean any of it.
My dad likes to say, “The more, the more.” 68.  46
That’s because your dad has everything. And then he gets more. (off her look) No, he’s right. There’s enough to go around for everyone.
Yo, Yosh! You got a pitch you got to attend! She kisses him.
Good luck.
Jamie walks with Josh through stopped traffic toward the Goldman Sachs building.
Remember, ask him questions. You're interviewing him. He’d be goddamn lucky to invest in your film.
Okay.
And talk about shit he understands, see. Short and to the point. A bike messenger swerves by them on the sidewalk.
(suddenly furious) Ride on the street, man! (and then back to Josh not missing a beat) Psych him up. Talk about money. Talk about war. Power. Race. Make it relevant to him.
Right.
Be yourself, everyone else is taken. Jamie straightens Josh's jacket collar.  47 Blue (09/16/2013) 70.
Ira was beautiful today. I’m gonna have a screening of the cut footage at the apartment on Friday.
You cut it already? We just shot it two days ago.
I know. I was up all night. (patting Josh on the back) We'll be okay, Joshy. Don’t you fret.
Maybe take a day or two to make sure you like it.
Or I can take ten years. Josh hesitates, taken aback. Jamie laughs.

I'm fucking with you, Joshy. Your thing is going to be totally brilliant. They reach the doorway of the office building. Jamie take the big headphones from around his neck and puts them on Josh. Jamie presses Play. “Eye of The Tiger” by Survivor.
I remember when this song was just considered bad! But it’s working.
Remember, he’s lucky to have this opportunity. You're friggin’ Josh Srebnick.
My name sounds so much better when you say it.
Josh shakes hands with a bulky fratty looking hedge fund 30’s, in a suit. This is Dave. Josh sits on a couch, Dave in an armchair. Dave drinks fr a highball glass.  71.
You see Mad Men?
No.
(waves it off) It’s really apple juice. Nah, it’s whiskey. Nah, it’s not. It is. He drinks.
So, tell me more about your project.
Well, maybe a good way to start is by asking you a question.
Hey, they were all raped when I got there. Josh stares at him blankly.
(re: highball) This is my second in twenty minutes. Shoot.
Do you know the percentage of African American adult males currently in jail?
I don't.
Take a guess.
(playing along but not really thinking) Like 60%?
Jesus, no! (pause) It's over 9%. That's nearly 1 in 10 African American adult males, nearly a million and half.  72.
A million and a half is a lot.
It's insane, but people don't realize this. They think because we have a black president...
(as if he's helping Josh out) So this is about prison. Like a black Shawshank. But real. A real, black Shawshank.

(thrown) No, not...no. (pause and then speaking quickly) There's a section, an Entr'acte really, on the function of race in the prison industrial complex... (trying to get back on track) But the film is really about how power in America works... Do you know the historian, Ira Mandelstam?
Yeah.
(pleased) Really?
No.
Well, we have over a hundred hours of interviews with him. Now --
The movie’s a hundred hours?

No, we'll cut it. Now, this guy, he’s not particularly charismatic, he’s kind of anti-social, maybe asbergers, but not interesting asbergers. He’s kind of boring even. But he’s a charismatic thinker.  73.
How do you show what he thinks? Cartoons?
(what?!) No, not cartoons. He says it.
But he’s boring.

Well...yes, but like many boring things, the longer you watch it, it takes on a different dimension -- Josh wipes the sweat that has now accumulated on his face Dave's glance goes to his Blackberry. He types something quickly.
Mmm hmm. So, what’s it about?

It’s really a very simple idea. The three sections correspond to the three nodes of what Mills called the power elite: the political, military and economic. But, and this is key, each part has to interconnect to show how none of these three nodes functions without the other. Dave tries to surreptitiously glance at his Blackberry.

It’s a linear film of course, but I imagine it as a kind of hypertext. To be clear, the film is really about the working class and, I can’t speak on behalf of the working class. I can't make their film, of course. They have to be felt as the impossible subject of the text. Through an examination of the power structure the voice of the working class has to be revealed in the margins through its very absence. If that makes sense. The phone rings. Both Dave and Josh look at it.
Hey, I’m suddenly so popular.  48 49 74.

(barrels on) But it’s not even really about the power structure but about what it means to make a film about it. It’s about the very possibility of making this film...It’s really about America. Dave can’t help it. He lunges for the phone. The sound of KNOCKING. INT. BREITBART’S APARTMENT - DOORWAY. DAY 48 Josh stands in the doorway, he wears his bike helmet and holds his hat. Breitbart smiles.

I was just working on my speech for my memorial. What’s on your mind, son? Josh nervously unstraps his bike helmet and puts on his h An awkward exchange as he has trouble holding both. He exhales. Breitbart finally accommodates by taking the hel
Would you watch what I have? I think I’m at a point where I need a new set of eyes.
Ten years with the same project will do that to you.
Yeah.
(warmly) Of course I’1l watch it. Come in, son.

INT. BREITBART’S APARTMENT - LIVING ROOM/KITCHEN. DAY 49 They watch the scholar on Breitbart’s new TV. Josh can’t look at the screen, his eyes on are Breitbart. CUT TO: Josh, still watching Breitbart. The movie ends. Breitbart nods, shuts off the TV with a remote.
I just got this TV. It’s a smart TV.  75. He gets up and stretches, clearly very stiff from sitting so long.
I’1l put a kettle on. You want some tea?
Okay. Breitbart goes to his kitchen. Josh waits, impatiently.
Well, you have a lot of good material there.
Uh huh.
Lots to think about. I need to process it.
Uh huh. Breitbart reappears in the kitchen doorway.
Do you need the stuff about Turkish politics?
Yes, because it connects to what he’s saying about the shift in power in the contemporary global economy. And, of course, it relates back to the earlier stuff on the Ottoman Empire.
Right, but it feels like a detour. What about the lengthy history of the Triangle Shirtwaste Factory Fire? Do you need that?
The interview with Tillie Kupferschmidst’s great great niece? That’s the emotional center of the movie. That’s where things come together. Without that scene...why make the film at all?  76.
But it’s too long.
It has to be long. The point is it makes you uncomfortable.
(gently) I wasn’t uncomfortable, I was bored. The kettle goes off. Breitbart goes back into the kitchen Josh follows him in.
Well, maybe boredom is your defense from the discomfort.
(growing impatient) You just showed me a six and a half hour movie that runs about seven hours too long. I’m trying to help.
I understand, I understand. I think I need to shoot some more interviews --
(quickly) Don’t shoot anymore! You have enough.
Yeah? I just don’t think you're getting it or maybe there’s something about me or what you saw that’s clouding your judgement.
I’m telling you what I really feel.
I don’t believe it. I think you’re being deliberately critical.
Josh, I’m trying to help you.
Bullshit! Is it because Cornelia and I didn’t have children?
Oh, come on, Josh.  77.
We tried. There were miscarriages. I had to give her a shot in her ass every day for three months. It’s a huge fucking needle.
I didn’t know you tried so hard. She didn’t tell me. I thought you guys didn’t want kids.
We didn’t want to hope for something we probably couldn’t have. (collecting his things) This was a mistake.
I’m sorry you feel that way. Josh starts for door.
I know you think I didn’t reach my potential.
No, son, no I don’t think you did. (beat) Your first film was so wonderful and entertaining. We recognized ourselves in it. This is ungenerous, it’s like you took your ball and went home.
You know what? I’m sorry I didn’t become you.
I don’t want you to be me, Josh.
Yeah, right.
I‘1l see you at Thanksgiving.
I’m not going to eat another fucking fried turkey FYI.
Then make your own.  50 51 Blue (09/16/2013) Josh slams the door.
Josh walks up to a sign-post. His chain- severed in half. His bike is gone.

Fuck! EXT. HOUSING PROJECTS, BASKETBALL COURT. Jamie aggressively drives to the basket, a jump shot over a leaping defender. He teammates as they hurry back on defense. Josh watches through a chain link fence. 78. 50 link chain has been
pulls back and makes fist bumps his CUT TO: Jamie, sweating, sees Josh through the fence. He jogs over and they talk through the chain-link.
Yosh! How did you find me?
(sheepishly) There's like eight different ways to find out where you are on the internet. And also through people we both know.
Ha! You want to play?
Nah, I don’t have the right shoes. (pause) Hey, I was thinking...you know how you asked...maybe, if you’re still up for it, I will co-direct with you... Jamie hesitates.
You know...if that’s still cool?
I’m not sure, Yoshy, I’m...at this point, I’m kind of in it, you know?
(his face turning red) Uh huh.  Blue (09/16/2013) 78A.
I mean, I’m kind of into doing it all now... I mean...you know?  52 79.
Uh huh.
I better get back to the game. I’11 see you tonight, yeah?

(quickly) Yeah. INT. JAMIE AND DARBY’S APARTMENT, BUSHWICK. DAY 52 Josh enters -- he’s late. The space is packed -- mostly w a sea of 20-something kids who lie on top of each other o the floor watching Jamie’s movie. Tipper, dressed up ina sort of Mary Jane outfit and horn-rimmed glasses, perched on a table, watching very seriously, her arms wrapped aro her long bent legs. Jamie stands in back, he looks nervou Darby a few feet away from him is texting. Cornelia waves from a crowded corner. Josh smiles wearily. Kent talks soberly on screen.

In the report it says we followed procedure. A flashlight, three flares, and the hand signals... A quick jerky zoom into Kent, missing his face and then adjusting to find him. He does the hand signals, punctuat them with:

.---bum, bum, bum...but that’s not how I remember it. It was sheer fucking panic when the bus approached the convoy. We opened fire -- Josh moves closer, looking for a place to sit or stand. H steps over a couple lying on the floor.
Ow. Those are my fingers.

Sorry, sorry. Josh stops in his tracks. Over on the side, the Moon Land headline above his head, stands Breitbart. To his right, hedge fund dude, Dave.  Blue (09/16/2013) 80. A light sweat breaks out on Josh’s face. Darby is looking straight at him. She gives him a sad smile. Josh looks ba at the screen. CLOSE: Josh’s scholar, Ira, talking about the politics of war. CUT TO: The movie is over. The mostly 20-something crowd laughs, drinks beers. Breitbart picks an Oreo from a bowl Oreos on a table. Josh pushes through the kids to find Jamie.
Yoshy!
You invited Breitbart?
Yeah, he called me after you introduced us.
He called you?
Yeah...and at our dinner I invited him to tonight.
At “our dinner?” Dinner with him? When did you have dinner?
After he called me, he suggested we get dinner.
Uh huh. (pause) Where'd you go?
This beautiful joint, um, on the Upper West Side --
Jackson Hole.
Yeah! How’d you know?
That’s where he goes.  81.
Great burgers. Have you been there?
Yes, I’ve been there with hima million times.
Have you gotten the Buffalo burger?
Of course!
He dug the footage. (pause) Is something wrong?
I guess I wish you'd asked me before you just went to him...
Hey, I’m sorry. I called him actually just to ask him a question about how he shot something and we just got to talking, see, and he asked me what I was working on...
So you called him?
What?
You said he called you.
He called me back, yeah.
Does Cornelia know?
Very cool! Very cool. The hedge fund guy, Dave, does a double fist bump with Ja which they mime exploding.
I’m proud to be part of it.  Blue (09/16/2013) 82.
Dave, you know Josh.
(barely looking at Josh) Nice to meet you. (to Jamie) Seriously dude, this movie is kill- aaahhhh. (does a little dance) We're going to Afghanistan, we're going to Afghanistan...
(taken aback) You're going to Afghanistan?
To interview soldiers in Kent’s unit. We've got a butt-load of work to do before we go. I’m going to need help.
Afghanistan, Afghanistan! Josh starts to retreat into the crowd. He hesitates. It pains him to say this, but:
Um, if you have any other editing work, my guy Tim, is great and could use some cash.
That would be beautiful.
(defeated) I‘1l text you his info.

(to Jamie) Dude, I want you to meet Diane, she’s a reporter for the Times. Dave drags Jamie across the room. Darby takes Jamie’s arm he passes, she asks him a question. He replies tersely ba She walks away, pissed. Dave pulls Jamie onward. We MOVE in on Josh. Color vanishes from his face as a terrible sinking feeling enters his body. Two hands wrap around his neck like choking. He reacts.  83.
Ahh! It’s Cornelia. She smokes a cigarette.
I’ve been looking for you.

You're smoking? (ve: everything) What’s going on? This is like a fucking bad dream. Everyone is here doing weird shit. Where’s my highschool algebra teacher, Mr. Morelli riding a fucking turtle? Across the room, Breitbart is approached by Dave and Jami
(re: her dad) I had no idea Dad was coming. I saw him when I got here.
Are you sure? Are you sure you’re not just saying that?
Yes, Josh! Why would I lie to you?
Do you think Jamie came to my talk because he knew I was married to you? That this was all so he could meet your dad?
Josh, you know, the world isn’t a conspiracy against you.
You know, fuck you.
Fuck you. Don’t talk to me like that.
I’m saying “Fuck you” in that way Jamie and Darby say it where it’s not a real Fuck you, it’s a semi-playful Fuck you.  84.
We’re not Jamie and Darby. We don’t talk to each other that way. If you say Fuck you to me it feels like a real Fuck you.
It is real.
Fuck you. And not semi-playfully either!
Fuck you. Total real, cutting to the core: Fuck you.
Josh comes outside, furious. Darby is making out with a Latino guy who looks like a gang member.
Darby? Darby lets go of the guy and looks at Josh.
Hey, sir.
Are you okay?
Shit’s bad. (pause) You want to get some goat?
Josh and Darby eat at a table.
Crushes fade. Things lose their luster, you know? Maybe I’m just down on relationships right now.
What about Jamie?
Jamie’s in love with Jamie.  85.
I thought you guys seemed great.

You know how no one will ever pick up just a male hitchhiker? But if it’s a couple, you might pull over? I’m the girl so you'll pull over and pick up Jamie. (pause) Doing ayawasca I realized I never forgave my mom for dying and until I do I’1l never have a decent relationship with a guy.
When did she die?
When I was in highschool. She had ovarian cancer.
I’m sorry... (realizing) Isn’t that also how Jamie’s mom died? He talks about it in the film. Darby hesitates.
Why’d you let Jamie use your scholar?
I was trying out being generous. He'd do the same for me. That’s how you guys are.
(with sympathy) Oh, Josh... You’re such a man-fox.
A man-fox? I wish it didn’t need the “man” qualifier?
Because you’re like a hot dad. Without children. Suddenly, she pulls her chair over to him, leans in, and kisses him on the mouth. He slowly moves away.
We shouldn't... She slides her chair back to her side of the table. hesitates, embarrassed.
This is the part where I say, “I was a bet?!”
What?
You know those romantic comedies where the girl was a bet? He nods. She nods too.
Yeah. Just because they did, doesn’t mean we have to.
What...what do you mean?
She never told you? Jamie and Cornelia made out at the ayawasca. It was in the Papyrus reeds behind the pyramids. Josh looks staggered.
I'm sorry, I stole one of Tipper’s adderalls. You want to go dancing?
(now getting angry) Yeah, I’m not going home tonight.

head_text.subj: INT. AFTER HOURS GAY CLUB. LATE NIGHT

text: She 55 Darby dances with Josh amidst muscular shirtless gay men. throws himself into it, trying to lose himself completely
Thanks for meeting me so early.
56 Jamie sits across from Cornelia. She looks tired and distracted.  87.
We've got a butt-load to do. Dave needs a budget for Afghanistan.
I’m almost finished with it.
I’ve been reading a lot about Afghanistan. It’s crazy. You know no one’s ever been able to successfully occupy Afghanistan.
(looking at her phone to see if anyone called) Yeah...I’ve heard that.
I think we got something now. With your help, it can really be something. (pause) Leslie’s notes were awesome.
He’s smart that way.
And he’s really chill to kick it with. She hesitates, she wipes a tear from her chin.
I’m sorry. Josh and I had a fight last night and...he didn’t come home. Cornelia starts to cry. Jamie hands her a napkin.
Hey, hey, it’s going to be okay. Joshy will come back.
(wipes her face) Thank you. I’m sorry I’m like this.
Hey, no worries. (his eyes avert her) I was thinking, maybe you and your dad would want to work on my thing together. (MORE )
He seems to want to get involved. It might be kind of great, right? A moment, Cornelia studies him. Jamie inspects his fork.
I mean, you’re producing, but he could bless it essentially...
Bless it? Like a sneeze?
(smiles) I was thinking more like the Pope.
He doesn’t do that kind of thing --
I think if you asked him, he might. Cornelia hesitates. She says, suddenly:
Did you ever see Power Elite? Jamie gets up and exchanges his fork with one on another table.
What’s that? The corner of Cornelia’s mouth turns up.
(catching himself) Josh's movie! Goddamn, yes. I told him that. I loved that scene with the dogs. Jamie returns with the new fork.
When you went to Josh’s class, you knew Josh and I were married, didn’t you? And that Leslie was my dad.
(hesitates) Hey, I admire lots of people, I want lots of things. You know what I mean. We all want stuff -- it doesn’t mean we’re douche bags. (MORE )
You're a hip chick. You kissed me, you're married to my friend, but I get it --
I thought you were Josh.
The first time. Cornelia stiffens.
You know, but out of context, if other people heard about it, it might be misconstrued. Cornelia looks out the window. Josh is across the street.
Cornelia approaches Josh, he’s in the same clothes from l night. She’s furious.
Where were you last night?
I went dancing with Darby at an after hours gay club. (angry and suspicious) Is this some kind of private meeting?
Did you follow me here?
I follow him on Twitter! You can’t lie like we used to lie anymore. Everything is reported. Nothing is private.
There’s nothing going on --
Don’t lie to me. You kissed him. I know all about it.
I thought he was you, Joshy.  Blue (09/16/2013) 89A.
Don’t call me Joshy! You don’t call me Joshy.  90.
Sorry.
It’s all a pose...it’s like he once saw a sincere person and has been imitating him ever since! And you’re falling for it.
(shakes her head) I didn’t even like them! You convinced me how awesome they were.
They're entitled little brats. And don’t you see, this is alla plan. He wants to destroy me. Jamie appears across the street, he holds a small video camera. He waves at Josh.
Go back inside! Josh takes off his porkpie hat.
You and your father can have him. You always wanted a more successful me, so go for it.
What is wrong with you?
I didn’t know when we got married that you also wanted to play kissy face with the twenty-five year olds. I didn’t know you wouldn’t want to have kids.
I didn’t know it either. I didn’t know you'd never finish your movie.
I'll finish it! I want to get it right.
It’s obsession. It’s fear. I don’t know. (MORE )
It’s not really about making anything. At least Jamie makes something!
Do NOT compare what I do with him.
Why not? When you felt a part of it, you loved it. (Josh says nothing) And you use your career as an excuse not to do anything. We don’t make decisions, we don’t go on vacations, we don’t have kids.
I want a kid.
You want it now that it’s impossible.
It’s not impossible.

No. It’s over. It’s done. I’m not putting myself through that anymore. (indicating her body) This is closed. Josh hesitates and then throws his hat into a garbage can He starts to walk away. He turns around, retrieves the ha from the garbage and walks away for real.
Josh blows into an air mattress.
Marina’s at a work dinner. Fletcher enters with a couple of old looking sheets. Will the baby, sleeps in a moby wrapped around Fletcher’s tors
They’re both top-sheets but...you know...
Thanks.  92.
You might wake up when I come through here for Willow’s 2 AM feeding. And then 5 AM. And then all the other times she wakes up.
That’s okay. Fletcher pours them both whiskeys. Josh picks up a cardbo sleeve from a Wilco CD off of a table. He smiles.
(re: the baby) How is she?
(looks down at her) Pretty good. Cool baby. To be honest, though, it’s a little hard for me to relate to an infant.
It seems kind of cool though.
It’s like the pregnancy is its own thing. You get so used to it. After a while I just felt, we did this, we don’t actually need the baby.
(nods ) I'm sorry if I’ve appeared crazy or...I don’t know...
I’m sorry we didn’t invite you to the party.
(shrugs) I think I’ve been jealous of you guys having a kid...

You know, before you have a kid, everyone tells you, “It’s the best thing you'll ever do.” As soon as you bring that baby back from the hospital, the same people say, “Don’t worry, it gets better.” It’s like, what the fuck was that all about before?  59
Having Willow must have changed your whole perspective on life.
(pause) Not as much as I hoped it would. (lowering his voice) I love my kid but I’m still the most important person in my life. Fletcher winces as he sits in a chair.
Did I tell you I have a herniated disk, C5 or some shit... I’m getting an epidurol on Monday.
(laughing) I have arthritis in my knees.
What the fuck is happening to us?
Josh waits outside an apartment door. A shirtless eight y old boy opens the door. Josh nods at him. Tim opens the door further.
Hey, man, I’m sorry about...not paying you.
Yeah...
I mean, I hoped the money would come in... It didn’t. I kind of fudged that.
I just can’t work for nothing, you know? The kid shakes Josh’s hand.
But thanks for hooking me up with Jamie, I’ve been freelancing a bit for him.  60 94.
If you’re not too busy there, I want to hire you back for a couple of weeks. I can pay you.
Did the grant money come in?
No, I sold all my CD’s. And some other things.
Tim and Josh sit in front of the screen.
Leslie suggested we cut the bit on Turkish politics, I told him it was crucial because of --
(immediately) I think it’s a good idea.
Yeah?
Yeah. We got to cut something.
(relents) Okay, let’s try it. Tim puts up an image on the SCREEN. It’s Kent.
Oh, this is Jamie’s footage. Stuff I was working on... Let me... He moves to take it down.
Wait --
What?
Hold on that image of Kent.
Okay.  95. Tim freezes it.
(dramatically) Blow it up.
I can’t do that on this machine.
Really?
No. Josh leans in. He squints. His POV: CLOSE on the home-mad ice cream container in Kent’s hand. The hipster cow.
That’s Darby’s ice cream.
It looks like mint of some kind.
(distracted) It’s avocado. Tim unfreezes the image. We ZOOM in on Jamie.
...my mom was really sick with ovarian cancer, I was pretty promiscuous, but I couldn’t love anyone, I had body issues --
Darby was there before we were. Don’t you see, she brought Kent the ice cream.
(confused) I know Jamie’s your friend, but to be honest, he’s kind of a prick. On SCREEN, Jamie’s open, earnest expression, his eyes wat and full of emotion.
CLOSE on Josh. His face is intense, his arms grip the whe  62 63 64 96.
(absent-mindedly singing) “You're playing Nintendo. That’s not what I’m doing, that’s not what I’m fuck-ing doing -- He bangs the wheel three times.
I’m fucking exposing your shit, mother fuck-ahhhhh --” EXT. KENT’S HOUSE, POUGHKEEPSIE. DAY 62 Josh rings the bell. The sister appears behind the glass. She wears a party hat.
Hey. Is Kent here? INT. KENT’S HOUSE/EXT. BACKYARD. DAY 63 Josh is lead by Kent’s sister through the house. We hear screaming in the backyard.
Is everything okay?
My son turns seven today.

Oh, happy birthday. They walk through the small space, stepping over toys and discarded plates of food and reach a cramped, uncultivate backyard. Kent, in a top coat and tails is pulling an end streamer out of his mouth. The kids scream with delight. INT. BREITBART’S APARTMENT. SAME 64 CLOSE: Cornelia stares intently into her father’s eyes. They're inches apart.
You’re so intense.
I'm focusing. We see now: Cornelia ties her Dad’s bow-tie. She’s very concentrated on the action.  97.
(finishing) There.
Thank you. He looks at himself in the mirror and approves.

It’s been very strange looking back over my career. How did I accomplish all of that? If I’m honest with myself: it sometimes took being a selfish prick. Of course, you can’t say that. In my speech I attribute it to talent, work and luck. It’s something I don’t think your husband realizes. He still believes the speeches.
When I first started dating him, he reminded me so much of you.
His problem is he wants what I have but he’s not merciless enough to get it.

(simply and sadly) You know I am disappointed in Josh. On some level I feel like he failed. But I don’t know if I actually feel that because I feel that or I feel it because he does. Either way it’s a terrible thing to think about your husband.
You know, Josh told me... I didn’t know you miscarried.
A few times. The magic of youth is that every decision is the right one and you don’t have to make any of them. The terror of adulthood is there are limited options and you have to pick.  65 98.
There’s no magic in being old. Some asshole tried to offer me a seat on the subway yesterday. She smiles. She takes her phone from her pocket and check it. No calls.
You young people are always checking your devices.

(embarrassed) I’m sorry...it’s habit. EXT. KENT’S BACKYARD. DAY 65 The kids smash a pinata with a baseball bat. Josh eats birthday cake off of a Space themed plate. Kent still in his magician clothes, does tricks for kids as th come by.
I learned magic from a dude, Elvin, over in Afghanistan. He was shredded by a land mine.
That’s terrible.
I’m more old fashioned in my approach. I don’t lock myself ina box or anything, it’s mostly cards and balls. I learn from YouTube videos. It keeps me from going out of my head.
Yeah...we need distractions. For me it’s the internet. I’m trying to go on less, you know. You know, it’s like how many times can I check the Huffington Post? Kent does a card trick for some kids.
It’s in your other hand! Kent opens his hand, the card is gone.  99.
How did you fucking do that?
Louis!
Sorry. What made you contact Jamie on Facebook? Kent looks at Josh strangely. Josh shovels a piece of cak into his mouth.
What do you mean?
(clears his throat) What made you reach out to him?
I didn’t. He contacted me. Kent indicates to Josh that he has icing on his face. Jos wipes at it.
Other side. I had no idea who he was.
Really?
He said he lived with Darby and that we'd gone to school in Santa Cruz together for a short time in the 90's. A kid hits Josh in the leg with the bat.
Ow! Fuck!
Louis, don’t be a prick!
Sorry.
(to Josh) And you, language.  100.
Sorry. (beat) But you remembered Darby...
Darby’s been a good friend for years. We'd Skype sometimes when I was in Kandahar. The reception was really shitty though. It would freeze up all the time.
Did she know about...that you were in the hospital? Kent hesitates.
Who are you again?
I’m Jamie’s cameraman.
And why are you asking this stuff?
Fact checking the movie?
Uh huh. Yeah, Darby knew. Darby was the first person I called. She came to visit a few times before you guys arrived. Some kids knock Kent’s top hat off and run with it across garden. Kent!
Bring that back, you fuckers!
Sorry.
What did you think when Jamie talked about Darby’s childhood as if it was his own?
He said he was playing a part.  66 101.
He said that when?
He called me a week or so before you guys came up and filmed me. Josh reaches into his pocket and takes out a small portab video camera. He turns it on and shoots Kent.
Can you say that again? INT. BREITBART’S APARTMENT. DAY 66 Cornelia, on her phone, has stepped away from her Dad who practices his speech in the background. She gets Josh’s voice-mail.

Josh...it’s me...again...I just...I am so sorry...I hope you come to my Dad’s thing, he’d like it and I'd like it and...I’m so sorry for all the things we said and I said and...I haven't said and...I’ve said but haven't said to you. This sounds cryptic, and maybe insane, but it’s not. I just, can you call me back? Can you come, please? (beat) Where are you, Josh? The doorbell rings. She brightens.
Wait! Maybe this is you! She hangs up and hurries to the door.
I got it! She opens the door: a hand extends from behind the wall, clutching a dozen roses. She is touched:
Josh, I... Jamie steps into the door-frame.
Jamie, actually. Don’t worry, it’s not weird. These are for your dad.  67 68 102. Cornelia’s expression drops.
There he is!

location: JAMIE AND DARBY'S APARTMENT, BUSHWICK. LATE DAY 67

text: Josh leans on the buzzer.

location: JAMIE AND DARBY'S APARTMENT. LATE DAY 68

text: Darby opens the door. A duffle bag and suitcase, computer and cat carrier with mewing cats are at her feet. Josh enters. He’s sweaty and dirty and angry and out of breath from the trip.
I’ve got to talk to Jamie!
He’s not here.
Are you going somewhere?
(embarrassed) Tampa. If I stay here any longer I‘1l girl interrupt.
I was just with Kent.
(with real feeling) Oh...Kent...I love Kent...
I saw your ice cream in Jamie's video. Darby nods. She smiles sadly.
Well played, sir.
He let me think I was the one who found out about Kent in Afghanistan. Why?
Jamie doesn’t want to disappoint you. None of us want to disappoint you. (MORE )

You're such a purist. Jamie would never have made the movie without Afghanistan. When I told him about Kent and the massacre he thought it would make a good movie. He just had to figure out how to tell it.
But why not tell it honestly?
It’s more entertaining this way. (beat) And now it has a before and after which, as you know, Americans love.
Of course he had body issues, they were yours. (off her look) I don’t mean, of course you had body issues, but... (pause) People have to know. He can’t get away with this.
Jamie does whatever he wants.
This goes against everything he said he admired in me. The whole principle of making a doc. Darby, you don’t understand. This is fraud. It’s a big deal. People are jailed for this kind of thing.
I don’t like to meddle with people. If they’re going to change, they’1l change.
Where is he?
He’s at your father-in-law’s tribute.
(realizes) Oh, shit! That’s now! And I returned the rental car. (ve: his appearance) I’m a mess.  69 70 71 72 Blue (09/16/2013) 104.
I can give you a jacket. And you can take Jamie’s roller blades.
Thanks.
(she goes to retrieve the items ) You know, me and Jamie always wondered how are we going to get old and the answer is: just like everyone else.

Josh, in a thrift store jacket over a hoody, jeans and sneakers attempts to roller blade, trying to get some momentum, but he can’t really skate. A woman, 50’s, on a Bike whizzes by him. A little kid on a scooter rolls past

Breitbart and Cornelia enter the building among suited patrons. Photographers shoot Breitbart who wears a suit w a scarf. Jamie hangs back. He’s more dapper than we’ve se him in a suit and wide colorful tie.
Can we get one with you and your daughter! Breitbart takes Cornelia’s hand. Cameras click. Then Jami steps into the shot. More cameras click. A photographer leans in to Jamie, holding a pad and pen.
What’s your name?
Me? Jamie Massey.
Tables are set up for a big dinner. Breitbart and Corneli take their seats. Dave leans over from an adjacent table shakes Breitbart’s hand. Jamie plops down next to Corneli  Blue (09/16/2013) 104A.
Jeez Louise. I’ve never been to a rat fuck like this. Did you see Lou Reed?
We see Josh appear on the horizon, blading toward us. He’ getting the hang of it now. We come in CLOSE on his inten determined face. He can do this!
