text: Josh rolls through, swiping as the passes.
Josh stands in his blades holding onto the bar.

location: STREETS OUTSIDE LINCOLN CENTER. NIGHT A73

text: Josh stands in his blades pushing the walk button. Cars whizz in front of him.  73 74 Blue (09/16/2013) 105.
Josh blades across the plaza.

Josh enters from the back, disheveled and on his blades. He rolls to a railing that looks over the reception. The lights have dimmed and on a screen: A black and white CLI from the 60’s of a little boy getting a bath. Josh scans the tables and finds Breitbart’s group. The CLIP ends to applause. Jamie leans over and says something to Cornelia. She nods. Her gaze goes in Josh’s direction. Josh rolls backward and steps behind the bar.
Can I get a Shirley Temple? Josh nods and starts to pour her drink. The bartender sta at him.
What are you doing, dude?  Blue (09/16/2013) 106.
Can I stand here for a second?

No. Josh grabs a bottle of whiskey and rolls behind a plant. removes his blades and stashes them in the planter. Jamie gets up from the table and walks toward the rest-rooms. J slugs from his whiskey bottle, and follows along the back the hall.
A wide carpeted room with high ceilings. A view of the pa Jamie looks out the window. Josh appears behind him. Jami turns around, startled.
Yoshy! (beat) You okay? Is that my jacket? Are those my blades?
(sarcastic) Are they? Who knows, maybe they’re Darby's. Darby's, yours, mine. Cookie O’Puss.
(unfazed by Josh’s dig) Where have you been? Everyone's asking about you.
(slugs from the bottle) I was in Poughkeepsie.
Okay. Jamie watches Josh for a beat.
It seems like you made a whole lot of stuff up. Applause from the other room.
I don’t want to miss his speech
Breitbart takes the stage.
I’ve been thinking of tonight as my memorial for so long I had completely forgotten I had to actually be alive for it. (laughter) I was hoping I could just sleep through it...
Josh and Jamie.
You know, it’s your responsibility to be honest. People are going to believe it.
I didn’t do anything nobody else does --
(trying to make sense of that sentence) “I didn’t do anything nobody else...” You reveal everything and nothing. (beat, composes himself) You said you wanted to be a real documentarian.
I do.
I thought you were about process. Process and...ice cream. But you really will do anything to be successful...
Success isn’t my thing, Josh. It’s yours. Josh is about respond, he hesitates. Nods.  108.
Yeah, you're right, it is my thing. I have a fucked up relationship with success. I want it and I don’t have it. But what you have scares the shit out of me. You’re not uncomfortable at all.
Why should I be uncomfortable?
See, that I just find weird.
You're the only person who is weird about this. I asked you to co-direct --
Yeah, because you knew I'd say, No!
Breitbart’s speech.
Now people have criticized me and some of my colleagues saying that we were pretending to be objective when there is no objectivity.
Josh and Jamie.
Jeez, Joshy. Everyone does this kind of thing.
I don’t. I don’t do something like this. I’m trying to make movies to figure out the truth.
(incredulous ) Really?  80 81 82 109.
Yes!
Breitbart.
Okay, we were trying to capture truth, but the truth of experience, of being in the moment, of seeing something as it happens.
Josh and Jamie.
(sadly) I do know that documentaries are over.
Are you kidding? It’s what everyone is doing.

(indicating Breitbart) His documentaries are over. What you're doing is something else. If everyone is filming everything, what’s a documentary anymore? It has no meaning, it’s just shit you recorded! Is that old man talk? Maybe it is. You kids have been told you can do anything. You can’t. (beat) Well, you, Jamie, can, but most people can’t. Jamie shrugs. Josh, annoyed, imitates him by shrugging ba
Breitbart.  110.
What we were trying to say as filmmakers is that what we were filming was more interesting than we were...
Josh and Jamie.
You think everything is out there for you to have. It’s not.
Nobody owns anything. If I hear a song I like, or a story, it’s mine. It’s mine to use. It’s everybody's.
No it isn’t! That’s not sharing Jamie, that’s...stealing.
That’s old man talk.
I am an old man! Applause as Breitbart finishes his speech. Josh, embolden turns to Jamie.

I can’t let Cornelia and Leslie walk down this road with you. I want you to go in there and tell them what you’ve done. If you won’t, I’1l do it for you. For a brief moment, Jamie’s face elicits what looks like fear. It passes.
Okay.
I’m sorry, kid. But there are standards, there are...standards.
Josh walks with purpose toward the table. Jamie trails behind him.
Josh!
Sorry I’m late. (to Breitbart) Leslie, I caught your speech from the lobby, though and it was really inspiring, spot on...
Are you okay, son? Do you want to sit down?
Jamie has something he wants to tell all of you. Josh takes a seat and crosses his legs comfortably.
Go ahead. They all look at him and then Jamie blankly.
Not all of the stuff in my movie happened exactly as I said it did. (sighs) I played around with some of the time- line.
Okay.
(humbly) Yeah...
“Yeah?” And...
And what?
You did a lot more than that, come on. Josh stands back up. He says to the table:  112.
He didn’t even know Kent. Darby did. And Darby’s mother died of ovarian cancer. Jamie’s mom is probably alive and kicking in Idaho. He sits back down.
(trying to put an end to it) Josh, this is kind of my night --
You just need to hear this.
That's basically it. Josh leaps back up.
No, that’s not basically it! You knew that Kent had tried to kill himself...
Right.
Say it!
Josh, come on, let him speak.

The gist is the same. I authored a bit of how we came to it. I mean, I’m not that good a writer. If I made it all up, I'd be the best writer in Hollywood and...and Kent would be Marlon Brando. Breitbart laughs. Hedge Fund Dave laughs harder.
I never said it was amazing. I just said it was faked.
And some of the time-line was adjusted --  113.
Stop with the time-line crap! Josh pulls out his video camera and gestures with it.
Jamie knew that Kent tried to kill himself. That he’d been in Afghanistan. We didn’t just stumble upon it. It was rigged. Jamie invented the whole Facebook thing because he knew it would play better.
Kent wasn’t in Afghanistan?
No, Kent was in Afghanistan.
So, what’s the problem?
It’s...it’s...the way, the way he said that he found him is not true.
Kent served our country, you’re being offensive. Breitbart looks at Jamie.
Is what Josh is saying true?
Well...I did know, but I don’t think it really matters though, the movie’s not about that.
Of course it matters. Leslie, explain...
I don’t know that it matters totally in this case.
(shocked) What? Dave leans in from the next table.  114.
I don’t care.
(dismissive) I didn’t expect you to care. (quickly back to Leslie) Leslie, are you kidding me? You don’t care? You just gave a speech about authenticity!
(thinks about it again) Yeah, I don’t care.
I just think the movie works on many levels, the happenstance of it, to be honest, I find the least interesting part. Josh sputters, practically stomps his foot.

I can’t believe it! This movie isn’t worth the...RAM...it’s...stored on. (pointing at Jamie) He’s acon artist. Leslie, your generation of sit-ins and protesters and...pack rats would be horrified by this...demon!
You're hysterical, Josh.
(hysterically) I’m not hysterical! He swings his arm, gesturing, knocking a tray full of foo and glasses out of a waiter’s arms. It goes crashing to t ground.
Shit, I’m sorry, I’m sorry. He helps the waiter pick up the plates. Everyone at the table waits. Josh finally gets back up.
Cornelia...  115.
I don’t know. I think he’s an asshole, but the movie’s pretty good. And I'm sorry I think that. Jamie takes a seat and starts eating the dessert that was placed in front of him.
This is so frustrating! I’m going to get no satisfaction here, am I? This guy’s just going to win no matter what. Everyone at the table stares at Josh. His says with certainty:
This is not how the world works. We MOVE in on Josh. His face fills with emotion.
Why does it have to be one thing or another? Things change. Different things matter now.
Forget ethics then. What about me?! You played me. I was played.
(under his breath) But you acted in it.
Only because I thought it was real! (pause, with genuine feeling) I loved you.
I like you too! We’re friends.
(sadly) I really believed it. (his throat full of sadness) I was a bet!
Are you okay, son?  85 Blue (09/16/2013) 116. Josh wipes his face.
I’m not crying. I’m not. Josh's attention goes to a tiny camera in Jamie’s lap aim right at him.
Are you filming this?!

Josh, your sleeve is on fire. Josh's sweatshirt has dipped into the flame of a candle o the table and is indeed on fire. Jamie stands, grabs a pitcher of water and douses Josh. Josh drips, soaked. He shakes his head like a wet dog and dejected, moves to leave. He hesitates and turns to Breit
I took your note by the way. I cut the stuff on Turkish politics out of my film. You were right, I don’t need it.
I’m glad to hear that, son.

CLOSE: Kent, in his magician outfit, speaks to the camera DELETE? comes up on the SCREEN. YES is selected. The file is deleted. Josh puts the video camera back in his tote. He sits on t steps with his roller blades and whiskey bottle. Cornelia arrives. She holds a plate with a napkin covering it. She hands it to Josh.
It doesn’t matter that it’s faked. (Josh nods) It doesn’t matter because it’s not about Afghanistan and it’s not about Kent it’s about Jamie.

(sighs) In my head, when I was blading over, I swept in here and exposed everything. I was such a hero.  117. He lifts the napkin on the plate to see a piece of chocol cake drizzled with chocolate sauce and a fork.
Thanks. Cornelia takes a swig from the bottle.
When we first started seeing each other I was so jealous. I would get so upset when you’d talk to another girl at a party.
I know! I liked that...
I was so sure you’d fall in love with someone else and leave me.
Did you want me to?

I think I wanted to know that I wasn’t your only option. But you didn’t fall in love with someone else. Until you did. And then it was two people. (beat) I’m so sorry I kissed him. I really did think it was you at first...then I kind of kissed him again. I don’t know why I did it. I wanted to like him as much as you did. Josh starts to eat the cake.
(mouth full) I wanted so badly...I wanted to be admired. I wanted a protege.
I know.
He looked at me like I was a real grown-up person. Someone who has done things. For the first time in my life I stopped thinking of myself as a child imitating an adult.  Blue (09/16/2013) 118.
You feel that way too?
(nods ) I’m forty-four and there are things I will never do. Things I won’t have. (pause) What’s the opposite of “the world’s your oyster?” Cornelia’s eyes water. She nods.
I think I stopped taking you in.
Am I a failure?
You’ve never failed me.
But am I a failure?
I feel like I failed you. I wish we could go back and meet each other all over again.
I'd present myself differently. So I didn’t get your hopes up. Maybe not use the expression “conquer the world” so often.
You said that a lot.
I think it’s hard for me to have something be great every day and to acknowledge it. (smiles at her) I have something great every day. If we were different people, I’d ask you to renew our vows.
I think it’s nice to renew vows.
Maybe we are different people.  86 Blue (09/16/2013) 118A. Silence.
What are you thinking about?
Twenty years ago I was twenty-four. In twenty years I'll be sixty-four.
CLOSE on Willow, a year older, in a car seat.
Pink (09/30/2013) 119. Fletcher drives, Marina in the passenger seat. Josh and Cornelia in the back with Willow. Fletcher pulls up to th terminal.
Call when you get there!
We will, Fox. Josh and Cornelia get out of the car and grab the bags fr the trunk. Marina joins them. Fletcher steps out of the car, but hangs by the door.
You're going to be such great parents.
The guy is waving at me, we have to move, Marina! They changed the rules. (to Josh and Cornelia) See you when you get back. Marina hugs both of them.
Oh, Fox, I’m going to cry.
The cop is coming, Marina! We'll be back in a week.
Send pictures of the little man! We love you guys.
We love you too!
I love you, Fletcher.
I love you too but I’m not getting arrested for you. Marina!

CLOSE: An airplane departure screen. JFK to Port-au-Princ Haiti.  88 Josh sits outside the gate, bags at his feet. He plays game on his phone. Cornelia sits down next to him with stack of magazines. She hands Josh a yogurt.
Thanks. (re: her stack of magazines) You really need ten?
It’s three and half hours to Port-au- Prince. 120. a a Cornelia slides a photo of a Haitian baby out from betwee the pages of a hard cover book. She smiles.
I can’t believe it.
Me neither. He takes the photo from her. He gazes happily at it. opens a magazine.

Oh...look who it is. She She presents the magazine for Josh to see: CLOSE on a PHO of Jamie at Sundance. CLOSE on the PULL QUOTE: “Are you a hipster?” “Well, I’m of a certain age and I wear tight jeans.”
Jamie, in a black trenchcoat and a knit cap, is being interviewed by a cute interviewer in a parka.
But I’m just about out of the cool- age demographic.
What happens when you exit the cool- age demographic? Jamie thinks about this. 88  89 90 91 121.
I enter the power-age demographic. We MOVE down to Jamie’s lap. He holds a small video camer trained on the interviewer.
Josh hands the magazine back to Cornelia.
It’s out there. The evil is unleashed.
No, you were right, he’s not evil. He’s just young.
I heard from Darby, she Facebooked me.
Darby, her hair in a braid, a name-tag on her shirt which a parrot on it, runs a net through mud. A motorboat behin her.
She's an eco-tourguide at a wildlife refuge.
This mud is filled with organisms. She sticks her hand in the mud and pulls out a worm-like thing.
This is a nudibranch. And if you keep your eyes peeled you might spot a gopher tortoise or a woodstork.
Josh opens his yogurt. He pauses for a moment, looking at the container.  92 122.
(frowns ) What’s wrong?
No. Nothing. We’ll have a baby before this yogurt expires. Cornelia suddenly leans in hard, her face colliding with Josh’s.

(laughs) Oww, your teeth. They kiss long, intimately. Finally, they release. Both a grinning. In the row of seats across from them: A mom is going thro her tickets and itinerary. Her toe-headed one year old so is on his iPhone. Josh and Cornelia watch the little boy -- his fingers mov quickly, gracefully on the keys. He’s totally immersed in what he’s doing. Nothing else exists. Then he puts it to his ear. We CUT TO: BLACK. As the CREDITS ROLL we

A VIDEO IMAGE of Josh. He sits in an armchair looking at camera. He consults a piece of loose-leaf paper, and with Cornelia’s help from behind the camera, re-asks his ten y  123. worth of questions for his documentary.
